segment.source: Stand-Alone Delivery Scenario Overview
segment.target: Stand-Alone Delivery Scenario Overview

segment.source: Stand-Alone Delivery Scenario Overview
segment.target: Stand-Alone Delivery Scenario Overview

segment.source: Stand-Alone Delivery Scenario Overview
segment.target: Stand-Alone Delivery Scenario Overview

segment.source: The stand-alone delivery scenario is an ideal application virtualization solution for environments where either low bandwidth connectivity or no connectivity limits the ability of the Application Virtualization Desktop Client to stream applications from centralized servers.
segment.target: The stand-alone delivery scenario is an ideal application virtualization solution for environments where either low bandwidth connectivity or no connectivity limits the ability of the Application Virtualization Desktop Client to stream applications from centralized servers.

segment.source: In these environments, users often work remotely and device owners install applications by using Windows Installer files.
segment.target: In these environments, users often work remotely and device owners install applications by using Windows Installer files.

segment.source: You can use the Application Virtualization Sequencer to create sequenced applications that include Windows Installer files.
segment.target: You can use the Application Virtualization Sequencer to create sequenced applications that include Windows Installer files.

segment.source: These packages include the virtualized applications, publication information, and the necessary installer routines for installing the packages on the client systems.
segment.target: These packages include the virtualized applications, publication information, and the necessary installer routines for installing the packages on the client systems.

segment.source: The installer adds the virtual application package to the Microsoft Application Virtualization Desktop Client.
segment.target: The installer adds the virtual application package to the Microsoft Application Virtualization Desktop Client.

segment.source: The publication information is configured to load applications from a local location rather than stream them across a WAN.
segment.target: The publication information is configured to load applications from a local location rather than stream them across a WAN.

segment.source: Users can temporarily connect to a network to retrieve the Windows Installer files or can run them from a DVD.
segment.target: Users can temporarily connect to a network to retrieve the Windows Installer files or can run them from a DVD.

segment.source: The stand-alone delivery scenario provides users the following benefits:
segment.target: The stand-alone delivery scenario provides users the following benefits:

segment.source: Simple deployment operation.
segment.target: Simple deployment operation.

segment.source: Network and servers not needed at runtime.
segment.target: Network and servers not needed at runtime.

segment.source: Applications pre-cached and available to all users.
segment.target: Applications pre-cached and available to all users.

segment.source: The stand-alone delivery scenario has the following limitations:
segment.target: The stand-alone delivery scenario has the following limitations:

segment.source: Built-in, automated reporting is unavailable; reports must be generated with external reporting tools.
segment.target: Built-in, automated reporting is unavailable; reports must be generated with external reporting tools.

segment.source: Applications must be delivered to the client manually like the original Windows Installer files.
segment.target: Applications must be delivered to the client manually like the original Windows Installer files.

segment.target: Related topics

segment.target: How to Manually Install the Application Virtualization Client
